content: In a 53-page ruling that rejected a claim of unfettered executive power advanced by both the Bush and Obama administrations, United States District Judge John D. Bates said that three detainees at the United States’ Bagram Air Base had the same legal rights that the Supreme Court last year granted to prisoners held at the American naval base in Guantánamo Bay, Cuba. "http://www.nytimes.com/2009/04/03/washington/03bagram.html?_r=1&ref=politics" Oh wait a minute, I thought OBAMA was the one changed from Bush's POV on these people? At least that is ALL In have been reading on here about it.
reply: In a 53-page ruling that rejected a claim of unfettered executive power advanced by both the Bush and Obama administrations, United States District Judge John D. Bates said that three detainees at the United States’ Bagram Air Base had the same legal rights that the Supreme Court last year granted to prisoners held at the American naval base in Guantánamo Bay, Cuba. title: Judge Rules Some Prisoners at Bagram Have Right of Habeas Corpus

content: quote: Originally posted by crackerjacks61: In a 53-page ruling that rejected a claim of unfettered executive power advanced by both the Bush and Obama administrations, United States District Judge John D. Bates said that three detainees at the United States’ Bagram Air Base had the same legal rights that the Supreme Court last year granted to prisoners held at the American naval base in Guantánamo Bay, Cuba. "http://www.nytimes.com/2009/04/03/washington/03bagram.html?_r=1&ref=politics" Oh wait a minute, I thought OBAMA was the one changed from Bush's POV on these people? Typo?At least that is ALL In have been reading on here about it. The article went on to say... The importance of Bagram as a holding site for terrorism suspects captured outside Afghanistan and Iraq has increased under the Obama administration, which prohibited the Central Intelligence Agency from using its secret prisons for long-term detention and ordered the military prison at Guantánamo closed within a year. The administration had sought to preserve Bagram as a haven where it could detain terrorism suspects beyond the reach of American courts, telling Judge Bates in February that it agreed with the Bush administration’s view that courts had no jurisdiction over detainees there. Where did our man of change go? Sounds like Bush III. If the policies of George W were correct in this matter as I believe, then so are those of the current administration. They are one and the same.

"http://www.nytimes.com/2009/04/03/washington/03bagram.html?_r=1&ref=politics" Oh wait a minute, I thought OBAMA was the one changed from Bush's POV on these people? Typo?At least that is ALL In have been reading on here about it.

The importance of Bagram as a holding site for terrorism suspects captured outside Afghanistan and Iraq has increased under the Obama administration, which prohibited the Central Intelligence Agency from using its secret prisons for long-term detention and ordered the military prison at Guantánamo closed within a year. The administration had sought to preserve Bagram as a haven where it could detain terrorism suspects beyond the reach of American courts, telling Judge Bates in February that it agreed with the Bush administration’s view that courts had no jurisdiction over detainees there. Where did our man of change go? Sounds like Bush III. If the policies of George W were correct in this matter as I believe, then so are those of the current administration. They are one and the same.

And a real disgrace, as I said on the thread you link to: quote: Personally I regard this position of the administration a disgrace to American Ideals. If they are actually combatants, let them be held as POW's until the war is over, however long that may take. If they are criminals, then let us try them, either with a normal Military Courts Martial or a civilian court. Everyone is either a POW OR entitled to the right of Habeaus. The Constitution makes no distinction between citizens and non citizens. Habeaus, as I say above, doesn't protect the guilty - Anyone who is guilty of a crime can be tried - Either in a civilian Court or a normal Courts Martial. Dave

content: quote: the fact is his policy is right in line with Bush's. Oh horse manure ... it mirrors Bush on Baghram but it sure as hell doesn't on GITMO ... at least on the surface. Candidly though, I believe that if Bush could have figured out a face-saving way to shut GITMO down he would have done it. IMHO, the difference between Obama and Bush on GITMO is that Bush couldn't figure out a practical way to terminate the operation so didn't ... while Obama has promised MMC in 12 ... and has yet to find a practical way to make it happen.

content: "Everyone is either a POW OR entitled to the right of Habeaus. The Constitution makes no distinction between citizens and non citizens" If that's the case why make every mother's son have to learn the following: We the people of the United States, in order to form a more perfect union, establish justice, insure domestic tranquility, provide for the common defense, promote the general welfare, and secure the blessings of liberty to ourselves and our posterity, do ordain and establish this Constitution for the United States of America. Doesn't say we the people of Europe, Asia or Arabia. Oh, well whatever. Set the judges straight, they need to read the history of the country and annotations to the Constitutional Presidential powers of the United States. Some very intelligent Chief Justices gave their notable decisions in the early days including during 1860's. "http://www.law.cornell.edu/constitution/

content: quote: Set the judges straight, they need to read the history of the country and annotations to the Constitutional Presidential powers of the United States. The Presidents constitutional power to kill at will ends at the battle field where those should have ended as well. Instead they were too busy beating up soldiers that were trying to do the jobs we wanted and needed them to do. Clean up the filth. Once Bush made this a political issue, he lost and always will. Even The NAZIs got a trial, no matter what they did to who. In fact there is another one in the news today that is going to be deported for that very reason...to be placed on trial. and this is what 60+ years after the allegations? But yet we screw the pooch on some rag tag crazy idiot that wants to kill us by his own admission? Come on.

Some very intelligent Chief Justices gave their notable decisions in the early days including during 1860's. "http://www.law.cornell.edu/constitution/ You better reread the Constitution. Under the law, everyone is equal. Native, foreigner, doesn't matter. quote: Article Three Section 2. The judicial power shall extend to all cases, in law and equity, arising under this Constitution, the laws of the United States, and treaties made, or which shall be made, under their authority;--to all cases affecting ambassadors, other public ministers and consuls;--to all cases of admiralty and maritime jurisdiction;--to controversies to which the United States shall be a party;--to controversies between two or more states;--between a state and citizens of another state;--between citizens of different states;--between citizens of the same state claiming lands under grants of different states, and between a state, or the citizens thereof, and foreign states, citizens or subjects. Seems clear enough to me. Or are you suggesting that I can do anything I want to a foreigner? Well, I guess you are saying that. Dave
quote: Originally posted by rayevinsonsr: "Everyone is either a POW OR entitled to the right of Habeaus. The Constitution makes no distinction between citizens and non citizens" If that's the case why make every mother's son have to learn the following: We the people of the United States, in order to form a more perfect union, establish justice, insure domestic tranquility, provide for the common defense, promote the general welfare, and secure the blessings of liberty to ourselves and our posterity, do ordain and establish this Constitution for the United States of America. Doesn't say we the people of Europe, Asia or Arabia. Oh, well whatever. Set the judges straight, they need to read the history of the country and annotations to the Constitutional Presidential powers of the United States. Some very intelligent Chief Justices gave their notable decisions in the early days including during 1860's. "http://www.law.cornell.edu/constitution/
